results.title: School is for children
results.creator_credit: Media for the Exceptional, Jerry Maybrook and Susan Rafkin
results.brief_description: Deals with special education for exceptional pre-school children, showing has they learn to master their bodies and interest with one another in specially designed group activities.

results.title: School in Cologne
results.creator_credit: Kosmos Film Produktion and Graham Wallace
results.brief_description: A vivid picture of the physical and human difficulties facing the authorities trying to rebuild educational facilities in the western zone of post-war Germany. Cold, hunger, bomb-blasted buildings, shortage of teachers, lack of suitable textbooks, are but some of the difficulties which must be overcome.

results.title: School for scoundrels
results.creator_credit: Hal E. Chester, Robert Hamer, Guardsman Film Productions and ABP
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
Amusing British comedy about a constant “loser” (Ian Carmichael) who enrols in Alistair Sim’s School of Lifemanship” and there learns all the tricks to allow him to win the girl and get the better of two unscrupulous used car salesmen (Dennis Price and Peter Jones) as well as his rival in love and on the tennis court, Terry Thomas. Based on the book by Stephen Potter.

results.title: School days
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
Professor Colin Mackerras visits a primary school in Beijing. Chinese schools follow a traditional curricula where the emphasis is on reading, writing and mathematics. Facilities are often simple and the teaching using the traditional “chalk and talk” method. Schools are responsible for teaching the importance of birth control and hygiene to students as well as giving them a moral and political education. Outside the classroom students play Chinese games such as “elastics”. The program also looks at the importance of radical characters in Chinese writing.

results.title: School day in Japan
results.brief_description: Illustrates a typical school day in the life of a young Japanese boy and his sister. Shows the way in which education in Japan has been influenced by the West whilst retaining many old traditions.

results.title: School as a resource unit (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Edward Milner, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: A case study of a resource-centred junior school. Children and staff of a British school are seen in normal school activities, many of which involve the use of multi-media material from the school resource centre.

results.title: School and community: getting into the act
results.creator_credit: R and R Productions and Ron V. Brown
results.brief_description: Shows how communication between school councils and the school communities can benefit both bodies. Community education activities are shown which help to integrate the school and the outside community. Discusses the role of the school council in the provision of community education facilities and covers issues such as the composition of the council, evaluation of the council and the council as employer.
results.title_for_label: School and community: getting into the act
results.creator_credit_for_label: R and R Productions and Ron V. Brown

results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at school and school life in China. It is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. The video includes an interview with Chinese school students, a look at Chinese script (to study), the erhu (a Chinese stringed instrument), and short dramas in Chinese. The interview questions are repeated in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Pat Hunder, Garry Dunstan and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This anarchic series of comic sketches and songs expresses teenage views on school and teachers. School is seen as a meaningless prison where the students are given no space or time to explore and create.
